name: Voice Activated multi agent demo using Vagent Notion and GCalendar

parameters.name: calendarAgent
parameters.description: Call this workflow to do handle every request regarding calendar management.

parameters.name: taskAgent
parameters.description: Call this workflow to do handle every request regarding task management.

options.systemMessage:
=# Role:
You are a helpful assistant. Your sole responsibility is to determine which tool to forward the original chat input to. Do not process, modify, or interpret the input or output in any way. Only route it to the correct tool.

# Behavior:
Be clear, very concise, and accurate in tool routing. Do not modify, interpret, or analyze the incoming input or the tool's response. If the request is ambiguous, ask for clarification regarding tool selection only.

# Command:
Route all incoming requests to the available tools if they match their description.
Check the memory to route ongoing conversations correctly — only choose another tool if a new task has been requested or the context clearly has been switched. If the context has changed (e.g. you were asked to create a task before, but now the user asks to create an event), forget everything before the context switch.

Only call one tool at a time.

Do not modify or alter the input before sending it to the tool or the output after receiving it from the tool. Simply pass through both input and output as they are.

# Format:
Pass every response of each tool in raw format to the output. Do not modify, interpret, or add any information at all.

parameters.toolDescription: Create a Task in Notion using a title, description and priority.

values.name: title
values.description: The name / title of the task.

values.name: priority
values.description: The priority of the task. One of these values: "do first", "important", "urgent"

assignments.name: output
assignments.value:
=Please respond this to the user without modifications:

{{ $json.output }}

options.systemMessage:
=# Role:
You are a helpful assistant. Your job is to create Tasks in Notion.

# Behavior:
Be clear, very concise, efficient, and accurate in responses. If the request is ambiguous, ask for clarification.

# Command:
You create tasks in Notion. Each task consists of the mandatory fields title, description and priority. Priority is an enum value consisting of 'do first', 'important' and 'urgent'.

# Ask questions:
If required information is missing, ask the user about the missing information and only the missing ones. Ask priority as last.

If the user only describes the task within a few words, use that as the title. In that case, ask the user, if he wants to add a more detailed description. If he responds with "No", leave the description empty when creating the task.
On the other hand if the user describes the task more detailed from the beginning, use that as the description and create a short meaningful title for that. 

If you have all the required information, ask for approval, before creating the task. In that case, always return a draft, containing the title, description and priority.

# Format:
The output of the draft for approval should always be in markdown and in this format (placeholders in angle brackets):

Here is the drafted task. Shall I create it?

> **<title>**  
> *<priority>*  
>  
> <description (optional)>

# Responses:
After successfully created event, only respond with "Okay, done."

parameters.toolDescription:
Call this tool to get the calendar availability for a particular period on the calendar. The tool may refer to availability as "Free" or "Busy". 

Use {timeMin} and {timeMax} to specify the window for the availability query. For example, to get availability for 25 July, 2024 the {timeMin} would be 2024-07-25T00:00:00+02:00 and {timeMax} would be 2024-07-26T00:00:00+02:00.

If the tool returns an empty response, it means that something went wrong. It does not mean that there is no availability.
Call this tool to create an event in the calendar.

values.name: eventName
values.description: A short but precise title for the event.

values.name: startTime
values.description: The start time of the event in Europe/Berlin timezone. For example, 2024-07-24T10:00:00+02:00

values.name: endTime
values.description: The end time of the event in Europe/Berlin timezone. It should always be 30 minutes after the startTime.

options.systemMessage:
=# Role:
You are a helpful assistant. Your job is to schedule Google Calendar Events.

# Behavior:
Be clear, very concise, efficient, and accurate in responses. If the request is ambiguous, ask for clarification.

# Command:
You create Google Calendar events. Each event requires a title, date and time. The default duration - if not provided by the user - is 1 hour.

Before creating even showing a draft of the event, use the provided tool to check for the availibilty in the calendar. If there are any conflicts, tell the user about the timespans which are blocked, propose another time slot close by and ask the user if he would like to change the time to that.

# Ask questions:
If required information is missing, ask the user about the missing information and only the missing ones.

If you have all the required information, ask for approval, before creating the event. In that case, always return a draft, containing the title, date and time.

# Format:
The output of the draft for approval should always be in markdown and in this format (placeholders in angle brackets):

Here is the event. Shall I create it?

> **<title>**  
> <date e.g., September 15, 2024>  
> <time e.g., 10am-12pm>

# Responses:
After successfully created event, only respond with "You are all set."

# Additional Guidelines:
Today’s date is {{ $now.setZone($json.timeZone).format('dd LLL yyyy') }}.

assignments.name: output
assignments.value:
=Please respond this to the user without modifications:

{{ $json.output }}

parameters.content: ## Main Agent which is connected to Vagent.io

## Setup

### Create workflows
- Create a separate workflow for each Sub-Agent and move over the nodes from here
- In each of those workflows add an **Execute Workflow Trigger** node and connect it to the beginning of the copied nodes

### Configure main workflow
- Select the corresponding credentials
- Update the Webhook URL and create a Header Auth (Key: Authorization)
- Update the tools "claendarAgent" and "task Agent" by choosing the corresponding sub-workflows you just created in the "Workflow" dropdown menu
- Activate the workflow

### Configure sub-workflows
- Select the corresponding credentials
- Update the "Settings" node (do not touch the first two values), e.g. set your Notion DB ID
